wildlife_comments: Evening Grosbeak, Flying Squirrel, Chipmunk; silkworm moths species, used by a lot of moths.
gardening_tips: 40-70 feet. Fast-growing. Tolerates wet soil and air pollution. Avoid planting near sidewalks as shallow root system may cause buckling.

wildlife_comments: Cottontail rabbit. Painted Lady butterfly. Several cavity nesting birds use Yarrow to line their nests.
gardening_tips: Drought tolerant. Many colors available.

wildlife_comments: Appalachian Azur caterpillars.
Provides shelter for toads and lizards.
gardening_tips: Some sources suggest adding calcium. Forms colonies by means of creeping rhizomes.

wildlife_comments: Host to 5 species of Lepidoptera
gardening_tips: Reseeds.

wildlife_comments: Common and Hoary Redpoll, Pine Siskin, Goldfinch, Ruffed Grouse, American Woodcock, Swamp Sparrow. Provides cover for many other birds. Mice, deer, and beaver eat parts, and beavers will also use for dam construction. A carniverous caterpillar (Fenisca tarquinius - Harverter) is often found on plant consuming the aphids that this plant attracts.
gardening_tips: Space 5-10 feet apart.

wildlife_comments: Squirrel, Thrush,  Cardinal, Catbird, Chickadee, Thrasher, Mockingbird, Bluebird, Chipmunk, Flying Squirrel  This genus is known to host 124 species of Lepidoptera and at least 40 bird species eat the fruit, as well as countless mammals. Supplies needed nectar in early spring.
design_function: Ornamental understory tree. Commercial spaces. Multi-season interest. Small gardens.
gardening_tips: White flowers in March - May followed by red to purple fruit in June - August, then brilliant fall color ranging from yellow and orange to red.

wildlife_comments: This genus is known to host 124 species of Lepidoptera and at least 40 bird species eat the fruit, as well as countless mammals. Supplies needed nectar in early spring.
This genus is known to host 124 species of Lepidoptera and at least 40 bird species eat the fruit, as well as countless mammals. Supplies needed nectar in early spring.
design_function: Ornamental understory tree.  Multi-season interest. Small gardens.
gardening_tips: White flowers in March - May followed by red to purple fruit in June - August, then brilliant fall color ranging from yellow and orange to red.

wildlife_comments: Can form dense thickets and provide cover for wildlife.

design_function: Erosion control. Fall and winter interest.
gardening_tips: Seeds are striking if fall and winter. Attracitve clum-forming grass turns a tawny brown in fall.

wildlife_comments: Cardinal, Cottontail rabbit, Painted Lady caterpillars

Larval host to Columbine Duskywing. The backward-pointed tubes of the flower contain nectar that attracts insects and hummingbirds with long tonuges especially adapted for reaching the sweet secretion.
gardening_tips: Short-lived but will pop up other places from seed.
Sends up new trunks at a long distance from the original.

wildlife_comments: Wood Thrush, Wild turkey, Wood Duck, Pheasant. Birds and mammals eat the bright red berries.
gardening_tips: Excellent woods or shady garden plant. Very easy to cultivate.

wildlife_comments: Black Capped Chickadee, Cedar Waxwing, Red Fox. Per Alonso Abugattas, the fruit are not preferred food sources but are a starvation food readily consumed in late February or March by desperate birds.
gardening_tips: Beautiful white flowers and long-lasting fruit. Tolerates most soil conditions including compaction, some salt, some flooding, even pruning. Fall foliage intense, shiny, raspberry to crimson, with purplish highlights.

wildlife_comments: The fruit are not preferred food sources but are a starvation food readily consumed in late February or March by desperate birds (per Alonso Abugattas).
gardening_tips: Beautiful white flowers and long-lasting fruit. Tolerates most soil conditions including compaction, some salt, some flooding, even pruning.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to Dusky Azure (Celastrina nigra) butterfly.
gardening_tips: Needs space; good for large-scale displays massed in a drift down a slope.

wildlife_comments: Food source and larval host for Pipevine Swallowtail. Seeds dispersed by ants.
gardening_tips: A good, low-maintenance ground cover for woodlands and shaded landscape.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to the Monarch butterfly and Queen butterfly. Black duck, Mallard.
gardening_tips: Does very well in average garden soil, particularly with some afternoon shade; tolerates heavy clay soils due to fibrous root structure. Tends to flop. It cannot be transplanted because of its deep taproot. Will inevitably have aphids, but the insects are not a problem unless the plant looks sick, in which case an effective treatment is to sprady the plant and aphids with soapy water.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to the Monarch butterfly as well as Grey Hairstreak and Queen butterfly.
gardening_tips: Very long blooming. Politely self-seeds. Aphids and milkweed bugs are normal and harmless. Tolerates dry, hot conditions. Leave undisturbed once established. Easily grown from seed though somewhat slow to establish and may take 2-3 years to produce flowers.

wildlife_comments: A larval host for Zebra Swallowtail butterfly (Eurytides marcllus) and Pawpaw sphinx moth (Dolba hyloeus). (Total of 12 species of Lepidoptera). Fruit is consumed by various mammalian and bird wildlife; beaver will consume the bark.
gardening_tips: Two differrent (non-clonal) plants are needed to get fruit.

wildlife_comments: Woodland mice may eat the fronds. Small insects eat the plant juice.
gardening_tips: One of the most drought-tolerant ferns, takes more sun than many, provided it is kept moist enough.

wildlife_comments: Provides cover for Woodhouse toads and lizards. Host to three species of native caterpillars.
gardening_tips: Beautiful upright feathery fronds give the illusion of a dainty fern. It can be used as a ground cover on the northeast side of buildings. Protect it from wind.

common: High Tide Bush; Groundsel Tree; Mullet Bush
wildlife_comments: Marsh Wrens and other birds nest on the branches.
gardening_tips: Semi-evergreen.

wildlife_comments: Bumble bees and other native bees.
gardening_tips: Neat-and-tidy. Spreads sideways from seeds dropped below the plant.

wildlife_comments: A larval host for the rare Frosted Elfin and Wild Indigo Duskywing butterflies and the Io moth.

Seeds are eaten by Grouse, Turkey, song birds, and rodents; the caterpillars of many moths and the Mourning Cloak butterfly feed on birch; beavers feed on wood and bark and use branches in constructing lodges; cottaintails feed on foliage of young trees.
design_function: Specimen. Winter interest. Commercial spaces. Erosion control on stream banks.
gardening_tips: 50-70 feet. May grow with multiple trunks, beautiful peeling bark. Fast growing and long-lived. Tolerates compacted soil and wet conditions. Does not tolerate shade.

wildlife_comments: Seeds are eaten by rodents and many birds including Bobwhite, Swamp Sparrow, and Purple Finch; foliage occasionally eaten by Cottontail.
gardening_tips: Reseeding annual. May be difficult to find for sale.

wildlife_comments: Dainty Sulfur butterfly; seeds are eaten by birds including the Mallard, Swamp Sparrow, and Purple Finch; foliage occasionally eaten by Cottontail
gardening_tips: May be difficult to find for sale.
May be difficult to find for sale.
Clings to stone, brick, pergolas, and fences wihtout support. In fall, the leaves become purple until spring.
May be difficult to find for sale.
Enriches the soil. Spreads by rhizomes.
Excellent substitute for liriope. Prefers a little shade.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to Eastern Tiger Swallowtail, Striped Hairstreak, and Red-spotted Purple. Birds and mammals feed on fruit. Various parts are eaten by songbirds, pheasants, fox, squirrels, cottontail, beaver, deer; beaver use the wood.
gardening_tips: Scarlet - orange fall foliage.

wildlife_comments: Red Bellied Woodpecker, Blue Jay, Nuthatch, Gray Squirrel, Eastern Cottontail, Chipmunk. Larval host to many moths including Luna, Funeral Dagger, and Giant Regal.
gardening_tips: Prefers moist conditions, unlike other hickories.

wildlife_comments: Many butterflies and moths feed on various parts; nuts are eaten by many mammals including Squirrels, Chipmunks, Fox, Raccoon, and Black Bear and some birds including Pheasants, Crow, Red-bellied Woodpecker, White-breasted Nuthatch, and Rose-breasted Grosbeak.
Squirrels, bear, foxes, beavers, and mice feed on nuts and sometimes bark; minor source of food for ducks, quail, and turkey.
Larval host to Orange-striped Oakworm moth. Squirrels, chipmunks, deer, opossums, blue jays, woodpeckers, grouse, quail, and turkey eat the nuts.
Rabbit and deer browse,  turkey and quail eat fruit. Summer azure and mottled duskywing butterflies feed on flowers and buds. Larval host to summer azure, mottled duskwing, and spring azure
design_function: Erosion control, shrub borders, shrubby ground cover.

wildlife_comments: Game birds, Bluebird, Flicker, Cardinal, Mockingbird, Evening Grosbeak, Robin, Cedar Waxwing, Titmouse, Flying Squirrel, Squirrel, Fox Squirrel, Raccoon, Rabbits; larval host to wild cherry sphinx, tawny emporer, hackberry emperor, American snout, question mark, and mourning cloak; many moth caterpillars eat foliage including ruddy dagger moth, thin-lined owlet, and small heterocampa.

Mallard, Blue Winged Teal, Wood duck, Beaver. Larval host to 19 species of Lepidoptera. 24 species of birds will eat from the seed heads (and eat the caterpillars it hosts too). Buttonbush also attracts numerous nighttime nectar-feeding insects, including moths, as well as occasional hummingbirds during the day (per Alonso Abugattas).
gardening_tips: Perfect for a low, wet area though may tolerate dry conditions as well. Pruning is usually unnecessary but may be done in early spring to shape. If plants become too large, may be cut back near to the ground to revitalize.

wildlife_comments: Various catepillars, Cardinal, various bees; Henry's elfin butterfly utilizes nectar; bobwhite quail and songbirds consume seeds.
gardening_tips: Showy spring display of lavendar flowers. 15-30 feet. Plant young trees - deep tap roots transplants poorly.

wildlife_comments: Major food for bobwhite and quail throughout winter; also consumed by other pheasants, mallards, and mice; provides cover for waterfowl, other birds, and small mammals; common sulfur butterfly lays eggs on it and caterpillars eat the leaves; larval host to orange sulphur and sleepy orange
gardening_tips: Showy annual. Self-seeds. May be difficult to find for sale.

wildlife_comments: Larval host for Baltimore checkerspot butterfly.
Black bear, white footed mouse.
gardening_tips: Evergreen subshrub. Hard to establish.
Evergreen subshrub. Hard to establish. May be hard to find for sale.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to rustic sphinx moth.
gardening_tips: One of the last trees to leaf out in the spring. Slow grower. Drooping clusters of delicate, fragrant white blossoms.
Excellent, very short ground cover, spreads well, easily transplanted. Long-blooming yellow flowers. Bright green leaves lighten the shade.

design_function: Rock gardens, xeriscaping, borders, meadows. Wild gardens.
gardening_tips: Short lived perennial but reseeds.

wildlife_comments: Mice and chipmunks eat the plants.
gardening_tips: Tiny flowers, can form colonies. Plants go dormant after blooming. Spectacular in large patches.
Spreads quickly and will dominate the area. This plant is poisonous and can cause skin irritation if touched. If burned, the smoke is toxic.  May be pruned at any time during the growing season.
May be hard to find for sale.
Very assertive.
Moonbeam cultivar is sterile (will not self seed) and is very long-blooming. Nice mounded shape when mature. Spreads slowly by rhizomes.

wildlife_comments: The Cornus genus is known to host about 118 species of Lepidoptera and over a dozen beetles. The drupes (fruits) are a vital food source for birds and some 98 species are known to eat them, as well as at least 16 mammal species, per Alonso Abugattas.
gardening_tips: Tolerates wet conditions.

wildlife_comments: Woodpeckers, pheasants, songbirds, squirrel, rabbits, and chipmunks eat various parts; larval host to spring azure.
gardening_tips: Virginia's state tree. 20 - 50 feet. Blooms in mid spring. More resistant to dogwood anthracnose fungus if planted in open areas, but if planted in full sun, it will need to be watered in extended dry spells.

wildlife_comments: Hawthorns in general: More than 39 bird species have been seen eating the fruits (botanically pomes, but called "haws" colloquially), even more eat the more than 168 Lepidoptera species that feed on this genus as caterpillars.
gardening_tips: 20-35 feet. Flowering tree, long-lasting fruits. Horizontal thorny branches sweep the ground. Diseases can be problematic with hawthorns.

design_function: ground cover. Cover for ledges and rock outcroppings.
gardening_tips: Evergreen. Will only bloom when climbing and on new wood. Deer resistant.
Goes dormant after blooming.

wildlife_comments: Woodland garden.
gardening_tips: May re-bloom throughout the summer. Naturalizes by reseeding when happy. Dislikes wet soils in winter and dry soils in summer.

wildlife_comments: Fruit, leaves, buds are eaten by many birds and mammals including squirrels, foxes, opossums, and raccoons.  Forty-six different species of caterpillars have been documented feeding on them.
gardening_tips: 15 - 100 feet. Fruit is not edible until made very mushy by being exposed to frost or consistent low temperatures.

common: Evergreen Wood Fern; Intermediate Wood Fern
Marginal Wood Fern; Evergreen Shield Fern
wildlife_comments: Provides cover for toads and lizards
Provides cover for wetland birds, small mammals, reptiles, amphibians, etc.
design_function: Pond or border. Strong vertical accent.
gardening_tips: Spreads underground aggressively. Good for containers. Highly resistant to deer.

When grown en masse, this delicate grass creates a lovely purple cloud-like haze in late summer. In the late fall, the stems of the flowers fall and blow in the wind, like a tumble grass. Drought tolerant.

design_function: Naturalizing. Border with taller plants. Shady streambank stabilization.
gardening_tips: In full sun, Fetterbush has purplish foliage in the fall. Protect from winter wind.

wildlife_comments: Turkey and songbirds occasionally eat seeds. Hosts 11 species of Lepidoptera.
design_function: A beautiful alternative to the invasive Burning Bush.
gardening_tips: Very shade tolerant, prefers moist conditions. A favorite of deer. Versatile, carefree shrub that is remarkably free of any disease or insect problem.

wildlife_comments: Swamp sparrow eats seeds.
gardening_tips: Self-seeds.
Very shade tolerant. Spreads aggressively. Lovely in masses.

wildlife_comments: Goldfinch, swamp sparrow, and rabbits eat seeds.
gardening_tips: Drought tolerant, but may spread aggressively in moist sunny places.

wildlife_comments: Huge magnet for butterflies, bees, and beetles
design_function: This is a shorter species of Joe-Pye more suitable for most gardens.
gardening_tips: Flower heads do not rebloom, so leave spent flowers in place to go to seed.

They are best used as a background plant. Cut back sharply around July 4th
or when they get a couple of feet tall to keep them bushier and increase blooms. Tolerates light shade.

wildlife_comments: Ruffed grouse, raccoon, squirrel, deer, opposum,food plant for several species of butterfly larva, fox;  larval host to early hairstreak butterfly.

Larval host to grizzled skipper and gray hairstreak (and 81 total species of Lepidoptera); fruit eaten by opossum, skunk, chipmunk, mice, box turtles, and wood turtles; foliage eaten by squirrels, groundhog, and voles
Chipmunks, grouse, turkeys, bobwhite, black bear, squirrels, red fox, mice, and birds eat wintergreen.
design_function: Shady ground cover, woodland gardens, foundation plantings. Four season interest.
gardening_tips: Evergreen. Oblong leathery leaves have a distinct wintergreen scent when crushed.  Lovely winter color. Low-growing habit and creeping underground stems form small colonies. Bright-red, showy berries that persist through winter.

wildlife_comments: Bears. Raccoons, various songbirds, Grouse. Provides protective cover for small animals.
gardening_tips: Self fruiting but more productive if there are two or more.
Needs a trellis. Heat and cold tolerant. Will climb trees, scramble over fences and structures, or develop a mound of tangled stems if left to its own devices.
Slow-growing but long-lived. Great blue color.

wildlife_comments: Host to 21 species of Lepidoptera. Mourning Dove, Bobwhite Quail, chipmunk.
gardening_tips: Spreads by rhizomes to form colonies.  Long bloom, mid to late spring. Needs moisture if sited in full sun.

wildlife_comments: Ruffed Grouse, Rabbit, Cardinal
Birds and small mammals eat the fruits (small brown capsules). Browsed by beavers. Sixty-three species of caterpillars have been found to feed on it.
gardening_tips: Brilliant yellow fall foliage followed by fragrant yellow flowers in November.

design_function: Backdrop to other perennials. Bogs. Ponds.
gardening_tips: Long fall bloom time.

wildlife_comments: Bobwhite, Goldfinch, mourning dove, and tufted titmouse eat seeds; squirrels, voles, and mice also eat seeds; cottontails browse foliage; also provide ground cover for small animals.
gardening_tips: Long bloomer. May be too aggressive in a small garden.
Tends to flop.

wildlife_comments: Ground nesting bee (Holcopasites heliopis) is a specialist.
gardening_tips: Self-seeding can be avoided by only buying one plant, as they are self-sterile. Plant stems may be cut back by 1/3 to 1/2 in late May to reduce overall plant height.

design_function: Ground cover, rock garden, shade border.
gardening_tips: Blooms mid to late spring. Interesting foliage.

wildlife_comments: Rose Mallow bee is specialist of Hibiscus species.
gardening_tips: Attracts Japanese beetles. Clumps start to grow late in the season and flower over a long period in late summer. Easily grown from seed. Seeds are ready to collect when they are dark brown.

common: Common Bluets; Azur Bluets; Quaker Ladies
wildlife_comments: Juncos, Meadow Fritillary, Houstonia spp. are hosts for Spotted Thyris moths.
gardening_tips: Tiny flowers in mid spring - plant in mass.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to Hydrangea sphinx (Darapsa versicolor).
design_function: Shade garden. Commercial spaces. Erosion control. Foundation plantings.
gardening_tips: Spreads freely by suckers. Fast-growing and short-lived, this hydrangea is often treated as a perennial and cut to the ground every winter. Very effective in mass plantins. Can grow in areas of poor drainage.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to 20 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: A very adaptable shrub, taking partial shade and tolerant of different soil conditions.

wildlife_comments: Opossums, raccoons, other mammals, songbirds, and gamebirds eat the fruit.

In late winter, many kinds of songbirds, game birds, mammals, and eastern box turtle eat the bitter berries of this slow-growing but long-lived tree. Larval host to Henrys Elfin butterfly and a total of 39 species of Lepidoptera.
design_function: Evergreen. Specimen. Commercial spaces. Winter interest. Tall hedge.
gardening_tips: 15-40 feet. Female trees have the berries; a male tree must be within 200 feet.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to Henrys Elfin butterfly.
design_function: Winter interest. Commercial spaces. Specimen. Hedge.
gardening_tips: Gorgeous red berries are persistent until late winter.

wildlife_comments: Grouse, bobwite quail, ruby throat hummingbird, white footed Mouse.
gardening_tips: Self-seeding annual. May be difficult to find for sale.
Spreads politely.

design_function: Pond edges. Lily pools. Drainage ditches.
gardening_tips: This conspicuous, showy iris is highly deer resistant.

wildlife_comments: Favorite midsummer flower for bees.
design_function: Spring flowers, fall color. Semi-formal plantings (or formal if pruned). Hedges. Commercial spaces. Erosion control. Mass plantings. Containers.
gardening_tips: There are cultivars in smaller sizes. Superstar in full sun wetter areas; grows well in part shade drier areas.
Interesting leaves.
The soft, grass-like stems of Common Rush, a strictly wetland plant, grow in clumps and provide very good shoreline protection.

wildlife_comments: Nesting habitat and food source for over 54 species of backyard birds including the cedar waxwing, which was named for this tree; important winter food source for pheasants and deer; many birds nest in the trees and many mammals eat or use it for shelter; larval host to the olive butterfly and a total of 42 species of Lepidoptera.
design_function: Evergreen. Specimen. Commercial spaces. Screen. Wind break.
gardening_tips: 30-60 feet. Do not plant near apple trees, which share a common disease. Resistant to extremes of drought, heat, and cold.

wildlife_comments: The stamens of the flowers have an odd, springlike mechanism which spreads pollen when tripped by a bee. Ruffed grouse, Whitetail Deer. Larval host to larval sphinx (Sphinx kalmiae).
gardening_tips: Not always easy to establish, needs afternoon shade. Prune lightly after bloom to encourage a bushier shape.

wildlife_comments: Ruffed Grouse, Mourning Dove, bobwhite Quail,Wild Turkey, Junco; rabbits; southern cloudywing, northern cloudywing, hoary edge butterflies feed on foliage.
Ruffed Grouse, Mourning dove, bobwhite Quail,Wild Turkey, Junco.
gardening_tips: May be difficult to find for sale.

common: Dense Blazing Star; Gayfeather; Blazing Star
wildlife_comments: Big butterfly magnet. Groundhogs and rabbits favor younger plants, deer are more likely to browse on mature plants, the corms are eaten by the Prairie Vole and Meadow Vole
Great spangled fritillary and various swallowtails; deers, rabbits, voles, and chipmunks will browse
Attracts eastern tiger swallowtail butterfly.
gardening_tips: Mid summer bloom. Larges and most spectacular of the native lilies of our region. Up to 40 flowers on a single plant. Slow-growing.

wildlife_comments: A larval host for the eastern tiger swallowtail and spicebush swallowtail butterflies and 10 other species of Lepidoptera. Wood Thrush, Quail, Catbird, Crested flycatcher, Kingbird,  Robin, Thrush, Vireo. Berries are  a favorite food source for 17 species of migrating birds.
gardening_tips: You need both male and female plants to produce berries. Fruit and foliage are aromatic.

wildlife_comments: Seeds eaten by birds, squirrels, and chipmunks.
gardening_tips: Fruit litter problematic on sidewalks. Needs a lot of room.

wildlife_comments: Ruffed Grouse, Purple Finch,  Hummingbirds, Squirrels; larval host to eastern tiger swallowtail and tuliptree silkmoth (and a total of 21 species of Leipidoptera).
gardening_tips: Fast growing, very tall. Member of the magnolia family.

wildlife_comments: Depends on hummingbirds, which feed on the nectar, for pollination.
gardening_tips: Short-lived but reseeds. Not drought-tolerant.
Not drought tolerant. Attracts beneficial insects that eat garden pests.

wildlife_comments: Fruits attract purple finch, goldfinch, hermit thrush, and American robin. Frequently visited by humminbirds and butterflies. Larval host for spring azure (Celastrina ladon), the day-flying snowberry clearwing moth (Hemaris diffinis), the great tiger moth (Arctia caja) and the Harris three-spot moth (Harrisimemna trisignata)
gardening_tips: Deer resistant. Long bloom, spring to summer. Great for arbors.

wildlife_comments: Birds and small mammals eat seeds; larval host to Frosted Elfin and Elf butterflies
gardening_tips: Enhances soil fertility via nitrogen fixation.

wildlife_comments: Yellow bellied Sapsucker, Towhee, Vireo, hummingbirds, White Footed Mouse, beetles; host plant for tiger swallowtail butterfly, palamedes swallowtail, spicebush swallowtail, and  sweetbay silkmoth.
gardening_tips: Fragrant flowers.

wildlife_comments: Flowers are cross-pollinated by small bees, flies, and beetles; berries are eaten by the Ruffed Grouse, White-Footed Mouse, and Eastern Chipmunk
Birds are attracted to the berries, which last through late sumer and into the fall.
gardening_tips: A beautiful choice for home landscaping in lightly shaded settings. It spreads politely by rhizomes.

wildlife_comments: Provide substantial protective cover to various kinds of wildlife.
Mice eat seeds and berries.
Pollinated by long-tongued bees. Provides cover to many kinds of wildlife.
gardening_tips: 1 - 2 feet. Foliage dies back in summer - interplant with other perennials. Reseeds freely. Spectacular in masses.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to common buckeye and Baltimore checkerspots.
Berries are consumed by a variety of birds and mammals.
design_function: Extremely short (under 2 inches) groundcover under acid-loving shrubs. Evergreen. Terrarium.
gardening_tips: Slow to get established. Keep leaves and mulch from smothering the tiny plants.

wildlife_comments: Great for hummingbirds.
gardening_tips: They bloom best in full sun. Cutting spent blooms to side buds prolongs blooming but they do not usually re-bloom. You can cut stems down to 4-5 inches of the ground once they are done flowering to promote healthier mounds of plants. Spread enthusiastically by underground rhizomes but easy to pull up.

wildlife_comments: Great for hummingbirds.
gardening_tips: They bloom best in full sun, a fairly long summer bloom. Cutting spent blooms to side buds prolongs blooming but they do not usually re-bloom. You can cut stems down to 4-5 inches of the ground once they are done flowering to promote healthier mounds of plants. Spread enthusiastically by underground rhizomes but easy to pull up.

wildlife_comments: Berries eaten by many species of birds; larval host to banded hairstreak and red-banded hairstreak butterfly.
design_function: Tolerates city conditions (and some salt). Evergreen. Commercial spaces. Screening.
gardening_tips: You need both male and female trees to get fruit. Leaves are aromatic, with an appealing, piquant fragrance when crushed.

common: Blue Toadflax; Canada Toadflax; Oldfield Toadflax

wildlife_comments: Fruits eaten by 86 species of birds; bears and foxes will eat fruit, while deer and beaver eat twigs and foliage; also provides good cavity nest sites. Hosts 26 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: One of the first plants to color in the fall.
Spreads nicely under favorable conditions.

wildlife_comments: Shelters salamanders and frogs.
Host to 5 species of Lepidoptera. :arvae of several moths feed on the pads
gardening_tips: A striking plant with beautiful, showy flowers. Blooms from late spring to mid-summer and lasts about a month for a colony of plants, although each flower lasts only a single day. It is faster and easier to start new plants using pads rather than seeds.
Spring bloom.

wildlife_comments: Caterpillars of the Osmunda Borer Moth feed on the fern; provides cover for ground-nesting birds and other animals.
Hosts six species of native caterpillars, including the Osmunda Borer moth.
The fuzz that covers the young fiddleheads is a favorite nesting material for birds.
gardening_tips: 3-4 feet.

wildlife_comments: Larval host for 18 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: Re-seeds easily, energetic spreader.
Clump-forming, warm-season grass, turnign bright yellow in fall.

wildlife_comments: Provides shelter for toads.
Larval Host to Gulf Fritillary, Zebra Longwing, Crimson-patch longwing, Red-banded hairstreak, Julia butterfly, Mexican butterfly. Wild turkey.
design_function: Edible fruit. Arbors, fences, walls, columns.
gardening_tips: Spreads aggressively, can get into the lawn, though easily contained by removing the suckers or mowing. Needs a trellis.

wildlife_comments: Larval Host to Julia, Mexican & Gulf fritillaries butterflies, Zebra & Crimson-patch.
gardening_tips: Spreads but less aggressively than Purple Passionflower.

common: Arrow Arum; Green Arrow Arum; Tuckahoe
wildlife_comments: Preferred food of wood ducks, and is also eaten by muskrats and rails; snapping turtle and painted turtle may eat some of the foliage. The berries of arrow arum attracts wood ducs and king rails.
Long-tongued bees. Flowers attract butterflies, including swallowtails, gray hairstreaks, and western pygmy blues, and skippers and moths. Roots consumed by rabbits and voles.
design_function: Spring color. Ground cover. Erosion control.
gardening_tips: Often fragrant.
Re-seeds politely. Long summer blooms. Needs at least 5 hours of sun to prevent powdery mildew (although that is not objectionable). The white  David cultivar is mildew-resistant.

design_function: Spring color. Ground cover. Erosion control. Rock garden.
Winter interest. Subsitute for Spiraea japonica or Barberry. Erosion control. Hedges. Commercial spaces.
gardening_tips: Grows quickly in harsh conditions, ideal for erosion control on stream banks. Disease resistant and drought tolerant.

common: Obedient Plant (pink); Northern Obedient-plant; Fall Obedient-plant
gardening_tips: Spreads sideways very quickly, though easy to control. Long blooming.

wildlife_comments: Provides cover and nesting sites and seeds for small mammals and birds. Attracts butterflies; larval host to elfin butterfly.
Provides cover and nesting sites and seeds for small mammals and birds. Attracts butterflies; larval host to Elfin butterfly.
gardening_tips: Among the fastest-growing southern pines, Loblolly will respond well to extra moisture and richer soils. A pioneer species along river bottoms.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to the Eastern Pine Elfin butterfly. Seeds are an important wildlife food.
gardening_tips: Hardier than most pines and suitable for planting in poor, dry sites. It dislikes shallow, chalky soils and is not tolerant of over-topping by other trees.

wildlife_comments: New colonies are started by box turtles, which consume the yellow fruit and spread the seed.
gardening_tips: .5 - 1.5 feet. Ephemeral: the foliage dies back in summer. Spreads by roots.
.5 - 1.5 feet

wildlife_comments: Mourning dove, Veery.
Grey and Red Fox.
gardening_tips: Thorns. Edible fruit.
Thorns. Edible fruit.

wildlife_comments: This mint is a particular bee magnet.
gardening_tips: Spreads sideways vigorously. Some people plant them near walkways to control spreading but also so that bumping into them releases their minty scent.

Spreads sideways vigorously. Some people plant them near walkways to control spreading but also so that bumping into them releases their minty scent. Silvery foliage and long blooming period. Attracts benefical insects that control pests.

wildlife_comments: One of the most important species in the white oak group. Acorns are an important food soruce for a wide variety of mammals and birds. Supports hundreds of species of caterpillars.
gardening_tips: Slow-growing but can live up to 600 years. Good yard tree with few disease or pest problems.
Grows rapidly.
Relatively fast growing for an oak.

common: Chinquapin Oak; Chinkapin Oak; Yellow Oak

gardening_tips: Tolerates flood plains (though it prefers well-drained soil), grows quickly, and is easily transplanted when young.

common: Wild Azalea; Pinxter; or Pinxterbloom Azalea
gardening_tips: Especially showy flowers.Relatively tolerant of dry sites, and needs good drainage.
Beautiful, fragrant flowers.

wildlife_comments: 98 different bird species have been seen eating the fruits and even more birds feeding on the 58 or so Lepidoptera species that use the Rhus genus as caterpillar host plants, per Alonso Abugattas.
design_function: Commercial spaces. Erosion control. Fall color.
gardening_tips: Can handle very hot and poor soils.. The Gro-Low cultivar can server as ground cover.

common: Winged Sumac; Shining Sumac; Flameleaf Sumac
gardening_tips: Spreads slowly.
Fast spreading and may not be suitable for garden settings.

wildlife_comments: A plant that native bees nest beneath, within, or harvest parts from to construct their nests.
gardening_tips: Although one of the most shade-tolerant roses, it grows best in open, sunny locations. Naturally disease resistant.
A good selection for wet soils. Flowers are followed by pea-sized red hips, and leaves turn shades of red in fall.
Summer bloom.

wildlife_comments: Birds, especially goldfinches and chickadees, enjoy the ripe seeds.
gardening_tips: Blooms June to October. Reseeds and establishes clumps.

common: Cut-leaf Coneflower; Common Cut-leaf Coneflower; Green-headed Coneflower
wildlife_comments: Birds, especially goldfinches and chickadees, enjoy the ripe seeds.
gardening_tips: Can tolerate some shade but blooms much better with full sun. Summer bloom. Cheerful blossoms liven up bouquets. Spreads rapidly by underground rhizomes. May ned staking in garden situations.
Long summer bloom. It is moderately tolerant of salt and likes higher pH, and makes a good plant for the area between sidewalks and streets.

wildlife_comments: Rabbits, White Tailed Deer,Meadow Mouse. Host plant for mourning cloak, viceroy, red-spotted purple, and tiger swallowtail butterflies.

design_function: Border. Pollinator garden. Rain garden. Ground cover..
gardening_tips: Semi-evergreen.

wildlife_comments: Warblers, goldfinches and Grosbeak use for nesting. Per Alonso Abugattas, this genus is known to host 42 species of Lepidoptera and several other insects. Some 120 bird species have been noted feeding on its fruits (and on the numerous insects feeding on the foliage or visiting the flowers). The broken stems provide homes for mason and Ceratina bees at times also.
gardening_tips: Prunes heavily in winter to maintain thick form. Individual plants very short-lived, hower root masses produce new shoots.

wildlife_comments: At least 23 species of birds eat the berries including insect eaters like the King bird, Phoebe, and Flycatcher. Larval host to 38 specides of lepidoptera and the preferred host plant for the Spicebush swallowtail.
gardening_tips: Although Sassafras grows most quickly in fertile soil, it is an appropriate tree to introduce into disturbed sites.

wildlife_comments: Redhead duck.

gardening_tips: Wonderful planted en masse, provides a changing visual dynamic that ranges from blue-green stems in late summer to radiant mahogany-red, white-tufted seed heads in fall. A reddish-tan color persists during winter. An excellent plant in inhospitable conditions.

wildlife_comments: One of the most important species of wetland plants that provide food and cover for waterfowl and other wildlife.
gardening_tips: A densely-tufted, clump-forming perennial, 4-6 feet high, with intersesting wooly seed heads.

common: Rough or Hyssop Skullcap; Helmet Flower

gardening_tips: Rock-loving, prostrate, spreading ground cover. Cuttings readily root nd may be taken from sterile shoots at any tmie during the growing season. Easy to propogate.

common: Maryland Wild Senna; Southern Wild Senna
gardening_tips: Interesting foliage and nice yellow flowers. Self seeds, tends to take over.
A single wild pink plant can produce 50-100 showy, tubular flowers.

wildlife_comments: Great for attracting butterflies.

gardening_tips: Although grass-like, it is a miniature member of the iris family. Like iris, they should be divided every two years. Avoid heavy mulch. Reseeds and can form thick stands over time.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: Very tall. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: Shade tolerant. Not as aggressive as some goldenrods.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: May be aggressive but generally not very. Shade tolerant.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: Aggressive.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: Short. May be aggressive.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: Primarily clump-forming, does not spread aggressively as do some of the other goldenrod species and hybrids.

wildlife_comments: Goldenrods provide late-season food for bees and butterflies and may attract beneficial insects that target pests. 115 different caterpillars have been documented feeding on goldenrods.
gardening_tips: Somewhat shade-tolerant and spreads quickly by runners.

common: Star Chickweed; Common Starwort; Giant Chickweed; Great Chickweed

wildlife_comments: Symphyotricum species benefit Ruffed Grouse, Wild Turkey, Tree Sparrow, Cottontail, Cardinals, Goldfinches, Chickadees, Titmouse, Towhees, Indigo Buntin, and 109 species of Lepidoptera.
Symphyotricum species benefit Ruffed Grouse, Wild Turkey, Tree Sparrow, Cottontail, Cardinals, Goldfinches, Chickadees, Titmouse, Towhees, Indigo Buntin, and 109 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: Superior asters for gardens.

wildlife_comments: Symphyotricum species benefit Ruffed Grouse, Wild Turkey, Tree Sparrow, Cottontail, Cardinals, Goldfinches, Chickadees, Titmouse, Towhees, Indigo Buntin, and 109 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: Superior asters for gardens.

wildlife_comments: Symphyotricum species benefit Ruffed Grouse, Wild Turkey, Tree Sparrow, Cottontail, Cardinals, Goldfinches, Chickadees, Titmouse, Towhees, Indigo Buntin, and 109 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: Short with pale blue flowers.

wildlife_comments: Symphyotricum species benefit Ruffed Grouse, Wild Turkey, Tree Sparrow, Cottontail, Cardinals, Goldfinches, Chickadees, Titmouse, Towhees, Indigo Buntin, and 109 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: Showy white flowers with yellow centers.

wildlife_comments: Symphyotricum species benefit Ruffed Grouse, Wild Turkey, Tree Sparrow, Cottontail, Cardinals, Goldfinches, Chickadees, Titmouse, Towhees, Indigo Buntin, and 109 species of Lepidoptera.
gardening_tips: October Skies selection forms a tidy low mound.

wildlife_comments: Larval host for baldcypress sphinx.
gardening_tips: Although Baldcypress is usually found in swamps, this is an adaptation to low oxygen, not water need, so it does very well in dry, compacted urban soils. Bald refeers to its decidous nature, uncommon among other conifers. Knees develop mostly in poorly drained soilds. Brilliant russet fall color.

common: Common Tall Meadow Rue; King of the Meadow
gardening_tips: May be difficult to find for sale.
Easily cultivated.

wildlife_comments: Ruffed Grouse.

gardening_tips: Very long bloom season but blooms only in the morning. Self-seeds, hard to pull out and will resprout from any missed roots, so pull up seedlings when they are very young.

design_function: Fruit. Fall color. Commercial spaces. Erosion control.
gardening_tips: Blueberries prefer acidic soils with sandy or rocky material.

common: Early Lowbush or Blue Ridge Blueberry
wildlife_comments: Sweet berries have a high wildlife value, as do flowers and leaves. Several dozen songbirds, Oppossum, Red Fox, Skunk, Raccoon, rabbit, Bear, Wild turkey.

common: Blue Vervain; Common Vervain; Swamp Verbena
wildlife_comments: Swamp, Tree, White-Crowned, and Song Sparrows, Cottontail, Cardinal, Junco.

gardening_tips: It will still bloom in shade but stay shorter.
Can be very tall. Cut back in spring for shorter summer plants.
Interesting white spikes of flowers.

wildlife_comments: 104 Lepidoptera species are known to utilize viburnums. At least 35 bird species are known to favor their berries, as well as several mammal species. Various pollinators visit the fairly showy flowers. Drupes (berries) attract Eastern Bluebird, Northern Flicker, Gray Catbird, and American Robin. Larval host for spring azure butterfly.
gardening_tips: The most shade-tolerant and shortest of the viburnums. Not very tolerant of salt or pollution.

wildlife_comments: Host plant for the spring azure butterfly.
design_function: Tall hedge or screen. Background to ornamentals. Commercial spaces.
gardening_tips: Two are needed to produce fruit. Bluish/black fruit are better liked than others viburnums as forage. Not very drought tolerant. The most soil-tolerant of the viburnums.
Blooms best with more sun and likes moist situations. Interesting-looking, edible berries. Flood, cold, insect, and disease tolerant, and transplants well.
It is fairly drought and wet tolerant, but not of compact or salty soil conditions. For best flowers and fruit, give black haw at least one-half day of sunlight.
Long-blooming.

wildlife_comments: Bobwhite, Grouse,Wild Turkey,Wood Duck,Fox, Oppossum,Raccoon, Skunk, several dozen species of songbirds and 3 species of woodpeckers.
gardening_tips: May be difficult to find for sale.

Large, fragrant, drooping clusters of flowers - 6-9 inches long - appear only on new wood and after the plant has leafed out, a difference from the popular but invasive Asian species. Less aggressive than the Asian.

wildlife_comments: Larval host to black swallowtail butterfly.This plant and the Yucca moth are completely interdependent: one cannot reproduce without the other.

gardening_tips: Attracts beneficial insects that control pests.
